descriptions.title: Original Image
descriptions.text:
Here is the original photo -
A portrait of Audrey Hepburn taken by Yousuf Karsh.
I made 12 processed images from this original photo
with Processing language.
TAP to zoom | SWIPE to navigate
or Use Arrow Keys

descriptions.title: 01 : CRT
descriptions.text: This is my first try of pixel simulation.</br>Simulate rounded-rectangle pixels on CRT monitors.

descriptions.title: 02 : Spiral
descriptions.text: Draw a continuous spiral from the center of canvs</br>and change thickness of the line</br>by the brightness of original image.

descriptions.title: 03 : Alphabets
descriptions.text: Mapping alphabets on the canvas by the brightness of original image.</br>For example, M or W has much area than I or L.

descriptions.title: 04 : Bar
descriptions.text: Varying each module's bar height by the brightness of original image.

descriptions.title: 05 : Nodes & Links
descriptions.text: Scatter a lot of points on the canvas and link them by their relative distances.

descriptions.title: 06 : Donuts
descriptions.text: Use a modular SVG image and change the size of module by the brightness.

descriptions.title: 07 : Web
descriptions.text: Put more points than Node & Links (but in different manner) on the canvas & link them.

descriptions.title: 08 : Scribble
descriptions.text: Simulate random scribbles on canvas.</br>The thickness of the line is based on the brightness of original image.

descriptions.title: 09 : Triangle
descriptions.text: Divide canvas's area with modular triangles.</br>Triangle modules gives mosaic like patterns.

descriptions.title: 10 : Concentric Circles
descriptions.text: Make modules as concentric circles.</br>Each circle's thickness varies by the brightness of the original image.

descriptions.title: 11 : 3 Elements
descriptions.text: There are  just 3 kind of modules: </br>two arcs with differenc colors and a half-rectangle.

descriptions.title: 12 : Pyramid
descriptions.text: This image is made with a pyramid-like module. </br> Module's center point is decided by the brightness.
